short_description: The Breusch-Godfrey statistical test which is run against the residuals associated with a fitted model
long_description: It is a test which looks for the presence of serial correlation amongst the error/residual terms.  It is mainly employed to analyze the residuals produced by a univariate or multivariate regression (cross-sectional data sets).  With respect to regression models, it is expected that there would exist no serial correlation amongst the error terms in contrast, with time series, the expectation is that most likely their will exist serial correlation amongst the error terms.

input_tables.LangName: data or object or newdata or ... --> Langauges team can work with UAF team to come up with this field
input_tables.description: This function is executed against the residuals left over after running a regression.
input_tables.rDescription: This function is executed against the residuals left over after running a regression.
input_tables.name: Input

output_tables.LangName: data or object or newdata or ... --> Langauges team can work with UAF team to come up with this field
output_tables.description: The TD_BREUSCH_GODFREY function returns only a primary result set consisting of one row per unique series acted upon.   There are no secondary or tertiary result sets produced by this function.  The primary result set can be retrieved by issuing a SELECT against the analytical table containing the results.
output_tables.rDescription: The TD_BREUSCH_GODFREY function returns only a primary result set consisting of one row per unique series acted upon.   There are no secondary or tertiary result sets produced by this function.  The primary result set can be retrieved by issuing a SELECT against the analytical table containing the results.
output_tables.name: OutputTable1

argument_clauses.name: RESIDUAL_MAXLAGS
argument_clauses.description: Positive Integer value.  Maximum lag number for the residuals used in the auxiliary regression.  Also determines degrees of freedom associated with the test.

argument_clauses.name: EXPLANATORY_COUNT
argument_clauses.description: The number of explanatory variables that were present in the original regression; plus '1' if a constant was present: Example: the FORMULA('Y = B0 + B1*X1') has a EXPLANATORY_COUNT of '2'; '1' for 'X1' and '1' for the constant 'B0'

argument_clauses.name: SIGNIFICANCE_LEVEL
argument_clauses.description: The desired significance level for the test. Set to 0.01 or 0.05.
